title: New Boston company wants to help you record amazing dash cam videos - News and reviews
text:
A new company wants to provide car enthusiasts with a tool that allows them to shoot HD-quality videos without taking their hands off their wheel.
Boston-based Waylens, Inc. promises to “put the fun back in the driver’s seat” with a data-focused automatic camera system that connects to a vehicle’s computers with a wireless adapter. It is also offering a cloud-based software to store videos.
Related Links Boston is getting its first Tesla store ‘Wall of Death’ bike among 75 motorcycles at this new exhibit in Brookline Car Doc: Is it a good idea to buy parts online? Search New Car Specials Waylens co-founder and chief marketing officer Michael Schmidt says his company’s product is designed for true car buffs who “already have a relationship with their car” and who invest money in after-market equipment.
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below “We knew wanted to build a camera the motor industry would find attractive,” said Schmidt in a phone interview. He also believes car buffs will find the Waylens camera stands apart from other car-focused systems because it draws data directly from a car’s operating system.
Waylens released a brief video comparing the video from its system to footage from a GoPro Hero 4.
“We wanted this to look like it could belong in the interior of a high-end luxury vehicle with beautiful design,” said Schmidt. “I think we’ve achieved that, but I’m biased.”
Here’s how it works: Users can mount a Waylens camera to their car’s windshield using a suction cup mount. A device called an OBD-II connecter that is already paired with the camera through Bluetooth connects to the car’s computer port underneath the steering wheel. The OBD-II connector records car data, including speed and RPM, over the footage recorded by the mounted camera.
A remote that is also paired with the camera can be mounted on the steering wheel to help drivers make a note of specific highlights while they drive. The camera also acts as a Wi-Fi hotspot to transmit footage to a smartphone.
Waylens is also offering a mobile app, cloud software, and an editing system that allows users to store their footage, edit the highlights, and share their drives on social media. Schmidt says community-building is a key focus of Waylens’ technology.
“The mobile app will have a news feed where visitors can share their videos and cloud services where videos can be hosted,” he said.
Waylens launched a Kickstarter campaign on October 13 with the goal of raising $55,000. To date, the company’s campaign has raised over $335,000. Interested backers may buy packages starting at $299 that include a camera, OBD-II data connector, steering wheel remote, and a charging cable.
Schmidt said the Waylens app is not publicly available yet, only to consumers who purchase the equipment on Kickstarter.
10 cars packed with technology

Kelley Blue Book (KBB) looked at 2015 cars with starting prices under $20,000 and ranked the top ten “tech-savviest” cars. “We are coming to a point in the auto world where the coolest tech is no longer limited to the people who have the most money,” according to Micah Muzio, managing editor of video for Kelley Blue Book. “If you want cool features, it starts at the top but it ends up trickling its way down.” Photo credit: Honda Previous -- of -- Next 10. 2015 Dodge Dart: With the Dodge Uconnect system, you can use simple voice commands to make a call, play music, navigate, and control other aspects of the car. According to Consumer Reports, the 2015 Dart has good handling and a spacious interior in the front but a cramped interior in the back. Base price: $16,485-$23,095. Photo credit: Dodge Previous -- of -- Next 9. 2015 Toyota Corolla: The Corolla has a system called Entune that has a bunch of its own moblie apps and makes it easy to access useful apps like OpenTable and Pandora. Consumer Reports noted that the 2015 Corolla has excellent fuel economy, a “comfortable-enough ride for a small car,” and a spacious interior. Base price: $16,950-$22,955. Photo credit: Toyota Previous -- of -- Next 8. 2015 Kia Forte: On the exterior, you can get LED accent lights and taillights, while on the interior you can get the UVO connectivity system for phone, music, and navigation, and even a heated steering wheel. According to Consumer Reports, the Forte’s handling is very secure but not very agile, and it has a very good fuel economy. Base price: $15,890-$21,890. Photo credit: Kia Previous -- of -- Next 7. 2015 Subaru Impreza:It offers a variety of multimedia systems, butmost of the other tech for the Impreza are safety related, such as its rearview camera, EyeSight driver assist with lane departure warning, and pre-collision braking. The Impreza is one of Consumer Reports‘s top-scoring compact sedans, as it has secure, responsive handling and great fuel economy. Base price: $18,195-$23,295. Photo credit: Subaru Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next 6. 2015 Nissan Versa Note: Backing out of a parking space becomes quite a bit easier with the Versa Note’s Around View Monitor, and it has hands-free texting. Consumer Reports notes that even though this car is a subcompact, it has quite a lot of space and versitility, though it lacks in interior storage. Base price: $14,180-$17,960. Photo credit: Nissan Previous -- of -- Next 5. 2015 Jeep Renegade: This SUV has a 7-inch driver info system, rear park assist, and the Uconnect system, which makes music, navigation, etc. easier to do. According to Consumer Reports, the Renegade has some off-road capability and has large removeable sunroof panels. Base price: $17,995-$26,795. Photo credit: Jeep Previous -- of -- Next 4. 2015 Chevrolet Trax: The Trax has 4G LTE wi-fi to turn the car into a hotspot, which is rare for a car of its price, plus a rearview camera and the Chevy MyLInk infotainment system. Consumer Reports calls the Trax, “an ambitiously-priced budget model” of the Buick Encore, but says that it has a cramped interior. Base price: $20,120-$26,530. Photo credit: Chevrolet Previous -- of -- Next 3. 2015 Honda Civic: Much of the technology in the Civic comes standard, including a rearview camera and a customizable LCD screen. Consumer Reports notes the Civic is “roomy and reliable,” but said the touch-screen audio system can be confusing. Base price: $18,290-$29,390. Photo credit: Honda Previous -- of -- Next 2. 2015 Honda Fit: The Fit has very similar standard features to the Civic, including the blind-spot camera and backup camera. According to Consumer Reports, the Fit is very versatile, has a great fuel economy, and has responsive handling. Base price: $15,650-$20,925. Photo credit: Honda Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next 1. 2015 Mazda MAZDA3: Kelley Blue Book called the Mazda3 the “tech-savviest new car with a starting price under $20,000,” as it has many multimedia options and you can get an infotainment controller in the center console. Consumer Reports says that the Mazda3 is “fun to drive” and is the most fuel efficient compact car that isn’t a hybrid or diesel. Base price: $16,945-$26,595. Photo credit: Mazda / Mike Ditz
